title: What are your favorite U2 B-sides from their entire catalog (e.g., Love Comes Tumbling In, Dancing Barefoot)? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Dancing Barefoot”, by far!!! I mean…by very far!  The story goes way back in 1989, when the song was issued as one of the “B-side” tracks of the “When Love Comes To Town” maxi-single. The frenzy about U2, after their landmark “Joshua Tree” album was at its height globally. Following the “Rattle & Hum” double LP, the madness continued; thus, this maxi-single was issued also in Greece:  “When Love Comes To Town” - U2 (maxi single, Island 4903, 1989, GR) (source: Discogs: U2 - When Love Comes To Town). Things went like that: a little older she-cousin, very influential on me about rock music in my teenagerhood, came home holding this one on her arms, excited about their hit self-titled tune. She was (and still is) a strong Beatles fan (that reminds me of someone else, hmmm…) but, during that period, she was under the spell of Bono and his mates. “You’ve got to listen to this, young man!” she shouted fully thrilled almost the moment she entered into our home, coming directly from a local record shop. As far as I can recall, it was a hot summer day in Athens, we were on summer vacations, old enough to enjoy the company without parents around (which were on work that morning, anyway). Before I realized it, the brand new record was on the turntable, iced-coffees were made, some cigarettes were lit (parents were not home, mind you) and the party had begun. “When Love…” started blasting out (loud!) from the speakers- and it was a total killer! I already knew it from the radio, but it was a real pleasure enjoying it home, coming directly from my humble “hi-fi” system! It must have been also my early introduction to the “B.B. King” sound and name, as well. OK, it was fantastic, but no surprise here. Nevertheless, I was ready to repeat the track, when my cousin asked to “listen to the whole thing, I’ll leave it here for a few days, you can play it as many times as you want later”. OK, I succumbed, a bit reluctantly - these B-sides most of the time doesn’t mean that much (except when coming from a Beatles’ single, I guess). “It’s your record”, I thought, “and it’s brand new, let’s give it a spin”. And there it came! I was instantly enchanted from the very first chords of Edge’s guitar. Bono added more magic when came singing “She-is benediction, she-is addicted to he…”, the rhythm section entered, the song immediately developed fully and I was blown! What, for God’s sake, is happening here?! Is this a B-side?! No, this is a masterpiece, it felt almost otherworldly. I was left ecstatic and also wondering: “Why did they leave this one out of the album? Do they have better tracks than that?” To cut a long story short, I played this gem to death that day. And the next one. And the next-to-next one. Then, I taped it - and almost destroyed the tape form the repeated playing. I had two pals called home to have it a listen - and they were blown away, too. One of them left my home directly for the record shop to buy the single! It was the “talk of the day” in our (small) rocking guys company for days. And we all agreed that these days, U2 were “the biggest band on the planet”! It took us a while to discover that it was a cover - we were that thrilled. Indeed, the song is written by Patti Smith and Ivan Král. Originally, it came as a second single from the Patti Smith Group from her fourth album “Wave” (1979). I discovered the original cover years later and I was also blown away. The song is a musical, melodic masterpiece, enhanced furthermore by the almost whispering, hoarse voice of Patti - while the rest of the band is on top form! To be fair, I also post the original cover here:  “Dancing Barefoot”, Patti Smith Group, 1979 Funny thing: coincidentally, I’m very into Patti Smith Group’s records these days, being constantly amazed by the artistry and personality of Mrs. Smith! What a performer! But, for all the memories I wrote above, between the two, I am still in favor of the U2 cover. The original is brilliant, as well - but the cover was like “first time, first love”; you can’t beat that. That’s all! Now, I’m gonna spin that U2 maxi on the turntable once again! PS: Source for the songs: YouTube. I own no rights for the songs, images and artwork, whatsoever.

Easy one for me - Lady With the Spinning Head, the B-side for “One”. It spawned many of the songs on Achtung Baby. Here’s what Mr. The Edge had to say about it - “There was a song called ‘Lady With the Spinning Head’ which we were really struggling with. It eventually ended up as a B-Side. But we tried and failed to develop it so many times. It actually spawned three different songs, “The Fly,” “Ultraviolet (Light My Way)” and “Zoo Station”. If you ever listen to “Lady With the Spinning Head” you will hear elements of all of those songs. “Zoo Station” was a version that we took in a more industrial direction. Danny provided an incredibly mad intro which sounds like a keyboard but is in fact guitar on which I’m creating strange textures.”
